posts.title: China’s devoted, combative celebrity fan clubs
posts.text: Photo by Pien Muller on Unsplash 为什么选这篇文章 很久都没做过外刊翻译了，我承认我似乎确实有点犯懒了，这段时间感觉什么都没做成。然后今天，#肖战喜提经济学人# 的词条上了热搜，对此我十分惊讶的，因为《经济学人》关注的都是那些「大问题」，饭圈这种亚文化可能都入不了眼。于是点开文章看了下，顺便做了翻译。 中英双语 中文 英文 A true fan downloads multiple copies of the same song and insults rival stars.一位真爱粉会数次购买同一首歌，还会抹黑对家。 “The untamed”, a costume martial-arts drama, is one of the most-watched television series in China. Since its online release last year it has been viewed 8bn times. Its heart-throb star, Xiao Zhan (pictured), has gained a legion of fans. In October so many of them crowded an airport in Beijing to see him that they delayed a flight. 古装武侠剧《陈情令》是中国收视率最高的电视剧之一。自去年上线以来，它的播放量已达 80 亿次，主演该剧的明星肖战获得了一大批粉丝。去年 10 月，由于挤在机场想要见肖战的粉丝过多，导致了航班延误。 In February Mr Xiao’s devotees flooded the internet with complaints about a website hosting raunchy fiction about him. The government shut it down. In May a video went viral of a classroom full of primary-school students chanting: “Brother Xiao Zhan, you are very good!” The teacher who filmed them was suspended. 今年 2 月，肖战的追随者们在互联网上大规模地对一家网站进行投诉，该网站上有关于他的淫秽小说。5 月，一段拍摄于一间坐满了小学生的教室的视频流传开来，在视频中，小学生们高呼：「肖战哥哥，你真棒！」拍摄该视频的老师最终被停职。 Mr Xiao’s millions of admirers belong to what are known in Chinese as fanquan, or “meal circles” (because the word for meal sounds like the English word “fan”). These are passionate and sometimes combative online groups devoted to particular celebrities. The Chinese government has long demanded patriotism and good behaviour from stars, but it has placed few limits on fans. On the internet, where debate and organising are usually tightly controlled, fanquan enjoy rare freedom to do both. 在中文语境下，肖战的几百万粉丝都属于「饭圈」（因为「饭」这个词听起来像英文的「fan」）。「饭圈」通常以某一特定名人为中心，其行为往往充满激情、有时甚至富有斗争性。一直以来，中国政府要求明星热爱祖国、行为端正，但很少对粉丝做出限制。辩论问题和组织活动在互联网上通常会受到严格的控制，但粉丝在这两个方面却罕见地享有自由。 But as fanquan have grown, so too has official scrutiny of them. State media have criticised their “irrational” behaviour. Aviation authorities have pleaded with them not to stalk stars at airports. (Some fans buy information about their idol’s movements.) In May a member of China’s rubber-stamp parliament called on the government to “strictly rectify” fanquan because of the threat they posed to the “inheritance of red culture”. Mr Xiao, who is 28, has asked his fans to calm down. “I hope everyone puts their studies, work and life before chasing stars,” he said. 但随着饭圈的发展，官方对他们的审查也越来越多：国家媒体曾批评他们的「不理性」行为，航空当局请求粉丝不要在机场跟踪明星（有些粉丝会购买偶像的行踪信息）。今年 5 月，中国的一位人大代表呼吁政府「严格整顿」饭圈，因为他们会对「红色文化的传承」构成威胁。今年 28 岁的肖战要求他的粉丝们冷静下来，他说：「希望所有人把学业、工作、生活，都放在追星前面。」 Members of fanquan are mainly women in their 20s. Some teenagers join the fun, too. A government report shows that 12.8m internet users under 18 frequently engaged in “fan-support” activities. These include posting praise, attacking critics and insulting devotees of other stars. After Mr Xiao’s fans turned their guns on the sexually provocative fiction website, the site’s supporters boycotted brands he represented and filled their social-media pages with furious abuse. Among defamation cases that were heard by the Beijing Internet Court between January and November last year, nearly 12% were filed by celebrities, often against fans of rival stars. 饭圈的成员主要是 20 多岁的女性，这其中也不乏一些青少年。一份政府报告显示，有 1280 万 18 岁以下的网民经常从事「应援」活动，这些活动包括发布赞美的微博、攻击批评者和侮辱其他明星的支持者。在肖战的粉丝将枪口对准发布性挑逗小说的网站后，该网站的支持者开始抵制他代言的品牌，并在社交媒体页面上对其进行愤怒的谩骂。在去年 1 月至 11 月北京互联网法院审理的诽谤案中，有近 12% 的案件是由名人提起的，起诉对象往往是其竞争对手的粉丝。 Fandom also entails spending. Nearly 15% of fans born since 2000 lavish at least 5,000 yuan ($707) on their favourite stars each month—about 40% more than the average urban disposable income. Sometimes they crowdfund shows of affection, such as adulatory billboards in New York’s Times Square. More often they help celebrities ascend online charts. Take Mr Xiao’s latest single—he is also a singer— “Spot of Light”. In the first 48 hours after its release, it notched more than 25m downloads, a record. His fans reportedly helped by buying an average of nearly 66 copies each. 应援还包括了花钱。2000 年以后出生的粉丝中，有近 15% 的人每月至少为自己喜欢的明星花费 5000 元人民币（折合 707 美元）——大约比中国城镇人口平均可支配收入高出 40%。有时他们会用众筹的方式表达迷恋之情，比如纽约时代广场的那些谄媚的广告牌。更多的时候，他们会帮助名人登上网络排行榜。拿肖战的最新单曲《光点》来说——肖战也是一名歌手，在发布后的 48 小时内，下载量就超过了 2500 万次，创下了记录。据报道，他的粉丝平均每人购买了近 66 张。 Despite the unruliness of fanquan, the government may see occasional benefit in their ability to organise. This year the League tried in vain to encourage their members to praise animated idols named after Mao Zedong’s writings. The idea was scrapped within hours. 但是，饭圈并不总是可以利用的。今年，共青团中央试图鼓励饭圈成员赞美以毛泽东著作命名的动画偶像，但最终失败了，这个想法在几个小时内就被取消了。 一位真爱粉会数次购买同一首歌，还会抹黑对家。 古装武侠剧《陈情令》是中国收视率最高的电视剧之一。自去年上线以来，它的播放量已达 80 亿次，主演该剧的明星肖战获得了一大批粉丝。去年 10 月，由于挤在机场想要见肖战的粉丝过多，导致了航班延误。 今年 2 月，肖战的追随者们在互联网上大规模地对一家网站进行投诉，该网站上有关于他的淫秽小说。5 月，一段拍摄于一间坐满了小学生的教室的视频流传开来，在视频中，小学生们高呼：「肖战哥哥，你真棒！」拍摄该视频的老师最终被停职。 在中文语境下，肖战的几百万粉丝都属于「饭圈」（因为「饭」这个词听起来像英文的「fan」）。「饭圈」通常以某一特定名人为中心，其行为往往充满激情、有时甚至富有斗争性。一直以来，中国政府要求明星热爱祖国、行为端正，但很少对粉丝做出限制。辩论问题和组织活动在互联网上通常会受到严格的控制，但粉丝在这两个方面却罕见地享有自由。 但随着饭圈的发展，官方对他们的审查也越来越多：国家媒体曾批评他们的「不理性」行为，航空当局请求粉丝不要在机场跟踪明星（有些粉丝会购买偶像的行踪信息）。今年 5 月，中国的一位人大代表呼吁政府「严格整顿」饭圈，因为他们会对「红色文化的传承」构成威胁。今年 28 岁的肖战要求他的粉丝们冷静下来，他说：「希望所有人把学业、工作、生活，都放在追星前面。」 饭圈的成员主要是 20 多岁的女性，这其中也不乏一些青少年。一份政府报告显示，有 1280 万 18 岁以下的网民经常从事「应援」活动，这些活动包括发布赞美的微博、攻击批评者和侮辱其他明星的支持者。在肖战的粉丝将枪口对准发布性挑逗小说的网站后，该网站的支持者开始抵制他代言的品牌，并在社交媒体页面上对其进行愤怒的谩骂。在去年 1 月至 11 月北京互联网法院审理的诽谤案中，有近 12% 的案件是由名人提起的，起诉对象往往是其竞争对手的粉丝。 应援还包括了花钱。2000 年以后出生的粉丝中，有近 15% 的人每月至少为自己喜欢的明星花费 5000 元人民币（折合 707 美元）——大约比中国城镇人口平均可支配收入高出 40%。有时他们会用众筹的方式表达迷恋之情，比如纽约时代广场的那些谄媚的广告牌。更多的时候，他们会帮助名人登上网络排行榜。拿肖战的最新单曲《光点》来说——肖战也是一名歌手，在发布后的 48 小时内，下载量就超过了 2500 万次，创下了记录。据报道，他的粉丝平均每人购买了近 66 张。 尽管饭圈不守规矩，但政府偶尔会从他们的组织能力中看到好处：1 月 23 日，新冠肺炎病例的爆发地武汉市进入封锁状态后，饭圈在十天左右的时间里就筹集了 740 多万元的救灾款并协助分配；去年香港发生动乱，官媒发动饭圈向国外的批评者赞美「阿中哥哥」，他们照办了，还对抗议者进行谩骂，共青团中央称这是 # 饭圈女孩为国出征 #。 但是，饭圈并不总是可以利用的。今年，共青团中央试图鼓励饭圈成员赞美以毛泽东著作命名的动画偶像，但最终失败了，这个想法在几个小时内就被取消了。 A true fan downloads multiple copies of the same song and insults rival stars. “The untamed”, a costume martial-arts drama, is one of the most-watched television series in China. posts.title: Consume Less. Create More. It’s More Fun.
posts.text: 这是 Telegram 创始人 Pavel Durov 于 12 月 4 日发布的文章。你或许不知道什么是 Telegram，但从这篇文章中，你可以感受到 Durov 所提倡的反消费主义价值观，不过他本人作为一名富豪，提出这样的观点难免会让我们感到不真诚，但是就 Telegram 来看，至少他为人们创造美好事物的行动，是真真实实地存在着的。同时，在这个消费主义盛行的时代，一位有能力实现充分消费的人带来的反消费主义观念，的确也是个不错的视角。 中英双语 中文 英文 Big corporations use marketing to trick us into thinking that the solution to all our problems lies in buying more of their stuff. 大公司利用各种营销手段欺骗我们，使得我们认为购买他们的商品就是解决我们所有问题的方式。 The real solution is often the exact opposite: it consists in consuming less, not more. In most cases, our problems are caused by overconsumption in the first place. 但真正解决这些问题的方式却恰恰相反：不是增加消费，而是减少消费。在大多数情况下，我们会产生问题的原因，首当其冲就是消费。 For example, if you are overweight, you will be bombarded with ads for gym subscriptions or food supplements. But the key to losing weight is eating less – not new shoes and protein powder. 譬如，如果你体重超标，你就会被健身房办卡或减肥食品的广告轰炸。但减肥的关键是少吃，而不是买新鞋或者吃蛋白粉。 Or, if you struggle with headaches and stress, they will try to sell you headache pills and antidepressants. But to really decrease stress, you should start sleeping and walking more instead of consuming entertainment products and browsing social media late at night. Pills are never designed to be a permanent solution: they lose power over time and cause side effects that will in turn require more pills. Once you embark on the endless journey of consumption, you get stuck in a trap designed to make you miserable and corporations happy. 或者说，如果你被头痛和压力所困扰，广告会极力向你推销头痛药和抗抑郁药。但如果真要减少压力，你应该开始多睡觉、多走路，而不是购买娱乐产品和熬夜刷社交媒体。药物绝不是永久的解决方案：随着时间推移，药物的效力会减弱；药物还会产生副作用，最后结果是你得吃更多的药。一旦你踏上无休止的消费之旅，你就会踏入一个精心设计的陷阱里，这个陷阱会让大公司感到快乐，但会让你十分痛苦。 Through evolution, Mother Nature has equipped us to efficiently cope with deficits of resources, but it never prepared us for life in the relative abundance we have now. Today, more people die from obesity than from hunger, and more people suffer from anxiety caused by information overload than from lack of news. 自然以进化的方式让我们获得了高效率地应对资源不足的能力，但自然没有为我们准备好应对当下资源相对丰富的生活的方式。如今，越来越多的人死于体重超标而不是饥饿，越来越多人的焦虑来源于信息超负荷而不是信息匮乏。 Human DNA, our hardware, is obsolete. It stopped evolving about 10,000-20,000 years ago when we still lived in small hunter-gatherer communities. Back then, every sweet bite and every piece of information was extremely valuable. We now live in megacities, surrounded by tons of cheap sugar, but our DNA doesn’t know that. Our bodies still accumulate excess fat to prepare for harsh hungry winters that never come. Our minds cling to every disturbing piece of news telling us about threats that never materialize. 我们的硬件——人类的 DNA，已经过时了。大概在一两万年前，我们还生活在狩猎群体中的时候，DNA 的进化就已经停止了。那时候，每一小口甜食、每一条信息都弥足珍贵。今天我们生活在大城市里，被廉价的糖所包围，这一点 DNA 并不知道。我们的身体还在为那不再到来的冬季储备多余脂肪，我们的头脑会紧紧抓住每一条告知我们威胁的新闻，这些威胁永远不会发生，但它们却让我们感到不安。 This biological paradox is made worse by our economic system which emphasises GDP growth and maximized corporate profits. People are encouraged to increase consumption by both governments and corporations. It’s not a coincidence that the US, a country that excelled in economic growth in the 20th century, is also the most obese developed country in the world. Their market-driven society became too efficient for its own good. 在我们这个强调 GDP 增长和追求公司利益最大化的经济系统下，这一生物学悖论显得更为糟糕。政府和大公司都在鼓励我们增加消费。美国是 20 世纪经济增速最快的国家，也是全球肥胖率最高的发达国家，这并不是巧合。他们这个由市场驱动的社会似乎过于有效了。 Not only is this system harmful to humans, it is also unsustainable in the long-term. Unlike corporate appetites, our planet’s resources are finite. We became very efficient in making and selling ourselves stuff we don’t need, but it is the planet which pays the bill. Our bodies still expect us to be living in the pristine environment we had 10,000-20,000 years ago, full of green forests and clean lakes. As we keep destroying our own habitat in the eternal quest for economic growth, the number of diseases caused by pollution continues to rise. 这一系统不仅对人类有害，长期来看，它也无法持续。大公司的胃口是无限的，地球的资源却是有限的。在制造和向我们自己兜售我们不需要的商品时，我们格外有效率，但最后为之买单的却是我们的地球。我们的身体仍然希望我们生活在一两万年前那个森林遍布、水流澄澈的原始环境中。在我们追求永续的经济增长的同时，由环境污染产生的疾病数量不断增加。 I was lucky to become wealthy early in my life. By the time I was 22, I had a million dollars in my bank account, by 25 – tens of millions, by 28 – hundreds of millions. However, this has never been what made me happy. 我很幸运，年轻的时候就富裕起来了。在我 22 岁的时候，我的银行账户里就有了 100 万美金；到了 25 岁，这个数字变成了数千万；到 28 岁，这个数字则是数亿——但这从来不会带给我快乐。 My real luck was in realizing pretty early that the most rewarding kind of occupation is creating things, not consuming them. So instead of buying yachts, airplanes and expensive real estate, I focused on what I enjoyed most – creating social platforms that (hopefully) bring good to humanity. I spent most of my personal funds on Telegram for people to enjoy a free service that strives for perfection. 真正让我感到幸运的地方，是我很早地意识到了最有意义的职业是创造，而不是消费。所以我没有买游艇、飞机和昂贵的房产，而是把钱投到了最令我享受的东西上——创造（但愿能）给人类带来福祉的社交平台。我把我基金中绝大多数钱投到了 Telegram，让人们享受免费且力争完美的服务。 I consider the ability to create things for others the most valuable – and rewarding – asset of mine. I suspect one of the reasons I happened to get wealthy in the process of doing what I love is because money has never been an important goal for me. 我把为他人创造的能力视作我最宝贵，且最有意义的资产。我想我只是恰巧在做自己喜欢的事情的时候变得富有，因为对我而言，钱永远不是一个重要目标。 When I was a student, I liked building games and websites. Back then, it was considered an occupation for nerds. Promising students were expected to practice law or solve business cases. But I never really cared about how other people defined success. For me, success was in the ability to spend time creating things that I liked. 当我还是一个学生的时候，我喜欢制作网站和游戏。那时，人们认为这种事只有书呆子才会做，有前途的学生应该去从事法律工作或解决商业项目。但我从未关心他人是如何定义成功的，于我而言，成功在于能够花时间创造自己喜欢的东西。 I never regret not buying expensive stuff wealthy people like to surround themselves with. The only regret I have is not having more time to build things. 我从不后悔放弃那些富裕人士喜欢买来围绕在他们身边的东西，唯一令我感到遗憾的是，我没有更多用来创造的时间。 We live in an era when the possibilities for human creativity are endless. One can invent robots, edit genes, design virtual worlds… There are so many exciting unknown areas to explore. I hope that more people will discover the enjoyment of building things for others. I hope that one day we, as a species, will turn away from the self-destructive path of never-ending consumption to a fulfilling journey of creating a better world for ourselves and those around us. 在我们生活的这个时代，人类创造的可能性是无穷无尽的。一个人能发明机器人、编辑基因、设计虚拟世界……有如此多令人兴奋的未知可供我们探索。我希望会有更多人发现为他人创造事物的乐趣，我希望有一天，作为地球的一个物种的我们，能够摆脱永无止境的自我毁灭之路，转而走上为我们自己和周围的人创造更美好世界的充实旅程。 大公司利用各种营销手段欺骗我们，使得我们认为购买他们的商品就是解决我们所有问题的方式。 但真正解决这些问题的方式却恰恰相反：不是增加消费，而是减少消费。在大多数情况下，我们会产生问题的原因，首当其冲就是消费。 譬如，如果你体重超标，你就会被健身房办卡或减肥食品的广告轰炸。但减肥的关键是少吃，而不是买新鞋或者吃蛋白粉。 或者说，如果你被头痛和压力所困扰，广告会极力向你推销头痛药和抗抑郁药。但如果真要减少压力，你应该开始多睡觉、多走路，而不是购买娱乐产品和熬夜刷社交媒体。药物绝不是永久的解决方案：随着时间推移，药物的效力会减弱；药物还会产生副作用，最后结果是你得吃更多的药。一旦你踏上无休止的消费之旅，你就会踏入一个精心设计的陷阱里，这个陷阱会让大公司感到快乐，但会让你十分痛苦。 自然以进化的方式让我们获得了高效率地应对资源不足的能力，但自然没有为我们准备好应对当下资源相对丰富的生活的方式。如今，越来越多的人死于体重超标而不是饥饿，越来越多人的焦虑来源于信息超负荷而不是信息匮乏。 我们的硬件——人类的 DNA，已经过时了。大概在一两万年前，我们还生活在狩猎群体中的时候，DNA 的进化就已经停止了。那时候，每一小口甜食、每一条信息都弥足珍贵。今天我们生活在大城市里，被廉价的糖所包围，这一点 DNA 并不知道。我们的身体还在为那不再到来的冬季储备多余脂肪，我们的头脑会紧紧抓住每一条告知我们威胁的新闻，这些威胁永远不会发生，但它们却让我们感到不安。 在我们这个强调 GDP 增长和追求公司利益最大化的经济系统下，这一生物学悖论显得更为糟糕。政府和大公司都在鼓励我们增加消费。美国是 20 世纪经济增速最快的国家，也是全球肥胖率最高的发达国家，这并不是巧合。他们这个由市场驱动的社会似乎过于有效了。 这一系统不仅对人类有害，长期来看，它也无法持续。大公司的胃口是无限的，地球的资源却是有限的。在制造和向我们自己兜售我们不需要的商品时，我们格外有效率，但最后为之买单的却是我们的地球。我们的身体仍然希望我们生活在一两万年前那个森林遍布、水流澄澈的原始环境中。在我们追求永续的经济增长的同时，由环境污染产生的疾病数量不断增加。 我很幸运，年轻的时候就富裕起来了。在我 22 岁的时候，我的银行账户里就有了 100 万美金；到了 25 岁，这个数字变成了数千万；到 28 岁，这个数字则是数亿——但这从来不会带给我快乐。 真正让我感到幸运的地方，是我很早地意识到了最有意义的职业是创造，而不是消费。所以我没有买游艇、飞机和昂贵的房产，而是把钱投到了最令我享受的东西上——创造（但愿能）给人类带来福祉的社交平台。我把我基金中绝大多数钱投到了 Telegram，让人们享受免费且力争完美的服务。 我把为他人创造的能力视作我最宝贵，且最有意义的资产。我想我只是恰巧在做自己喜欢的事情的时候变得富有，因为对我而言，钱永远不是一个重要目标。 当我还是一个学生的时候，我喜欢制作网站和游戏。那时，人们认为这种事只有书呆子才会做，有前途的学生应该去从事法律工作或解决商业项目。但我从未关心他人是如何定义成功的，于我而言，成功在于能够花时间创造自己喜欢的东西。 我从不后悔放弃那些富裕人士喜欢买来围绕在他们身边的东西，唯一令我感到遗憾的是，我没有更多用来创造的时间。 在我们生活的这个时代，人类创造的可能性是无穷无尽的。一个人能发明机器人、编辑基因、设计虚拟世界……有如此多令人兴奋的未知可供我们探索。我希望会有更多人发现为他人创造事物的乐趣，我希望有一天，作为地球的一个物种的我们，能够摆脱永无止境的自我毁灭之路，转而走上为我们自己和周围的人创造更美好世界的充实旅程。 Big corporations use marketing to trick us into thinking that the solution to all our problems lies in buying more of their stuff. The real solution is often the exact opposite: it consists in consuming less, not more. In most cases, our problems are caused by overconsumption in the first place. For example, if you are overweight, you will be bombarded with ads for gym subscriptions or food supplements. But the key to losing weight is eating less – not new shoes and protein powder. Or, if you struggle with headaches and stress, they will try to sell you headache pills and antidepressants. But to really decrease stress, you should start sleeping and walking more instead of consuming entertainment products and browsing social media late at night. Pills are never designed to be a permanent solution: they lose power over time and cause side effects that will in turn require more pills. Once you embark on the endless journey of consumption, you get stuck in a trap designed to make you miserable and corporations happy. Through evolution, Mother Nature has equipped us to efficiently cope with deficits of resources, but it never prepared us for life in the relative abundance we have now. Today, more people die from obesity than from hunger, and more people suffer from anxiety caused by information overload than from lack of news. Human DNA, our hardware, is obsolete. It stopped evolving about 10,000-20,000 years ago when we still lived in small hunter-gatherer communities. Back then, every sweet bite and every piece of information was extremely valuable. We now live in megacities, surrounded by tons of cheap sugar, but our DNA doesn’t know that. Our bodies still accumulate excess fat to prepare for harsh hungry winters that never come. Our minds cling to every disturbing piece of news telling us about threats that never materialize. This biological paradox is made worse by our economic system which emphasises GDP growth and maximized corporate profits. People are encouraged to increase consumption by both governments and corporations. It’s not a coincidence that the US, a country that excelled in economic growth in the 20th century, is also the most obese developed country in the world. Their market-driven society became too efficient for its own good. Not only is this system harmful to humans, it is also unsustainable in the long-term. Unlike corporate appetites, our planet’s resources are finite. We became very efficient in making and selling ourselves stuff we don’t need, but it is the planet which pays the bill. Our bodies still expect us to be living in the pristine environment we had 10,000-20,000 years ago, full of green forests and clean lakes. As we keep destroying our own habitat in the eternal quest for economic growth, the number of diseases caused by pollution continues to rise. I was lucky to become wealthy early in my life. By the time I was 22, I had a million dollars in my bank account, by 25 – tens of millions, by 28 – hundreds of millions. However, this has never been what made me happy. My real luck was in realizing pretty early that the most rewarding kind of occupation is creating things, not consuming them. So instead of buying yachts, airplanes and expensive real estate, I focused on what I enjoyed most – creating social platforms that (hopefully) bring good to humanity. I spent most of my personal funds on Telegram for people to enjoy a free service that strives for perfection. I consider the ability to create things for others the most valuable – and rewarding – asset of mine. I suspect one of the reasons I happened to get wealthy in the process of doing what I love is because money has never been an important goal for me. When I was a student, I liked building games and websites. Back then, it was considered an occupation for nerds. Promising students were expected to practice law or solve business cases. But I never really cared about how other people defined success. For me, success was in the ability to spend time creating things that I liked. I never regret not buying expensive stuff wealthy people like to surround themselves with. The only regret I have is not having more time to build things. We live in an era when the possibilities for human creativity are endless. One can invent robots, edit genes, design virtual worlds… There are so many exciting unknown areas to explore. posts.title: After a Bad Year for Freedom, Try Liberalism
posts.text: Photo by Kristina V on Unsplash 为什么选这篇文章 我算是一个有点自由主义思想的人，2020 年算是自由主义完全溃败的一年，很多以往我所相信的东西，都在「疫情」前变得分文不值。不过仍然有人相信自由主义是有未来的，例如这篇文章，颇有种带着自由主义「突出重围」的感觉。 中英双语 中文 英文 A pandemic is by necessity a time for restrictions and Big Government. But if emergency measures become the new normal, liberty dies.大流行病必然会催生出大政府和各种管制，但如果紧急措施成为新的常态，自由必将消亡。 It’s been a terrible year for personal freedom. And I’m not just saying that because I happen to find myself in yet another lockdown. 对个人自由来说，这是可怕的一年。我之所以这么说，还不是因为我碰巧发现自己又经历了一次封锁。 Like war or other disasters, a pandemic shifts priorities. In 2020, individual liberty seemed less important and public health appeared most urgent. State paternalism suddenly looked surprisingly acceptable, or at least necessary. 像战争或其他灾难一样，疫情也会改变事务的优先级。在 2020 年，个人自由似乎不那么重要，最为紧迫的似乎是公共卫生问题。令人惊讶的是，国家家长制似乎突然变得可以接受，或者至少是必要的。 But along the way, Covid-19 also became an ideal pretext for cynics and autocrats everywhere who already disdained liberty to try to bury it altogether. As 2021 dawns, is freedom in global retreat? Is “liberalism” passé? 但在这一过程中，疫情也成了各地已经不屑于自由的愤青和专制者试图将自由彻底埋葬的理想借口。随着 2021 年的到来，自由主义是否在全球范围内退缩？「自由主义」过时了吗？ The outlook wasn’t all that bright even at the start of 2020. In January, I penned a “liberal manifesto” because I feared that classical liberalism was going out of fashion and a new collectivism was becoming vogue. Covid-19 has accelerated that preexisting trend. 实即使在 2020 年初疫情还没发生时，前景也不是那么光明。2020 年 1 月，我写了一篇「自由主义宣言」，因为我担心古典自由主义正在过时，新的集体主义正在流行，疫情不过是加速了这一既有的趋势。 To avoid confusion, let’s be clear about the word liberal here. It has nothing to do with its American meaning of lefty, woke or big government; nor with its European caricature as “neoliberal” and market fundamentalist. We’re talking instead about a venerable philosophy that regards individual freedom as the highest value while fully recognizing the need to harmonize this principle with society as a whole. 为避免混淆，首先让我在此阐明「自由」这个词的意思。这里的「自由」，与美国的左派、清醒或大政府没有任何关系，也与被讽刺的欧洲「新自由主义」和市场原教旨主义者无关。我们谈论的是一个古老的哲学概念，这里的「自由」将个人自由视为最高价值，同时充分认识到需要将这一原则与整个社会协调起来。 For that reason, liberalism can occasionally live with restrictions on liberty. The harm principle, as defined in 1859 by John Stuart Mill in his treatise “On Liberty,” says that “the only purpose for which power can be rightfully exercised over any member of a civilized community, against his will, is to prevent harm to others.” 正因如此，自由主义者是可以偶尔忍受对自由的限制的。约翰·斯图尔特·密尔在其 1859 的论文《论自由》中定义了损害原则，即「人们若要干涉群体行动中任何个体的行动自由，无论干涉出自个人还是出自集体，其唯一正当的目的乃是保障自我不受伤害。」（注：此为三联书店 2019 年版《论自由》译文，译者孟凡礼） So there’s nothing inherently illiberal about, say, a lockdown to slow the spread of Covid-19. Or about a regulation that requires us to wear masks in public. Nor is it automatically illiberal for the state, in a situation of economic disruption and distress, to step in temporarily as the primary economic actor, paying firms and people until they can earn their livelihoods again. 因此，从本质上来讲，并不存在什么「不自由」。比如说，利用封锁减缓疫情传播，或要求我们在公共场合戴口罩；在经济混乱和困难的情况下，国家作为主要经济行为者暂时介入，向公司和人民支付费用，直到他们能够重新谋生，这也不必然是「不自由」。 The trouble starts when these measures are adapted, extended or abused. The world was already tilting toward authoritarianism in recent years. China didn’t need Covid-19 to oppress the Uighurs or clamp down on Hong Kong, nor did Alexander Lukashenko need it to tyrannize Belarussians. But many autocrats have seized on the coronavirus as another excuse to crack down on their critics, the free press, minority populations and others they don’t like. 但当这些措施被调整、扩大或滥用时，麻烦就开始了。最近几年，这个世界开始向极权主义倾斜。中国不需要借疫情去压迫维吾尔族人、镇压香港，卢卡申科也不需要借疫情去对白俄罗斯人施行暴政。但很多独裁者已经抓住了疫情这一借口，以打压其批评者，打压媒体自由，打压少数群体和其他他们不喜欢的人。 Democracy and human rights have deteriorated in 80 countries this year, according to Freedom House, an American think tank. In Zimbabwe, government thugs have, in the name of policing lockdown infractions, arrested, abducted, raped or assaulted opposition leaders, activists and other dissenters. Authorities from Kazakhstan to Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Guatemala and many other places have been almost as bad. 根据美国智库 Freedom House，今年民主和人权在 80 个国家出现了恶化。在津巴布韦，政府暴徒以维持治安封锁为名，逮捕、绑架、强奸或殴打反对派领导人、社会活动家和其他异议人士。这样的恶劣场景，从哈萨克斯坦到斯里兰卡、柬埔寨、危地马拉和许多其他地方的政权中都有出现。 Even where governments don’t physically tyrannize people, they increasingly censor them digitally or, under the pretext of contact tracing, build new surveillance tools. China has gone furthest, by connecting biometric, financial and other intimate information about citizens without their assent. Even democratic societies such as South Korea and Singapore increasingly have an infrastructure they could turn from transparent to Orwellian with the flick of a switch. 即使在政府没有对人们进行身体上的暴政的地方，他们也会越来越多地对人们进行数字审查，或者以接触追踪为借口，建立新的监控工具。中国在这方面走得最远，在未经同意的情况下将生物统计学数据、金融数据和其他私密数据关联起来。即使是韩国和新加坡这样的民主地区，也有越来越多的基础设施通过轻轻地拨动开关，从高透明度变成了奥威尔式。 In mature democracies such as Germany or the U.S., checks and balances remain robust enough to prevent such dystopias for the foreseeable future. But there too the climate for democratic and civilized discourse, the precondition for any liberal society, has deteriorated. 像德国或美国这样成熟的民主国家，制衡机制仍然强大，足以在可预见的未来防止这种荒诞情况发生。但在这些地方，作为任何自由社会的先决条件的民主和文明对话的气氛也已经恶化。 The main culprits are conspiracy theorists, who always thrive in times of plague. They wantonly abuse the right to free speech and assembly — core principles of liberalism — to spread disinformation and lies. 罪魁祸首是阴谋论者，他们总是在瘟疫时期兴风作浪。他们肆意滥用自由主义的核心原则：言论自由和集会自由的权利，来散布虚假信息和谎言。 Liberals will be the first to defend these people’s right to disagree with government policies or to interpret medical facts differently. But when people misuse their own liberty to impugn facts and pervert truth they are vandalizing our intellectual, psychological and cultural commons. 自由主义者会首先捍卫这些人反对政府政策或以不同方式解释医学事实的权利。但当人们滥用他们的自由来质疑事实和歪曲真理时，就是在破坏我们的知识、心理和文化公域。 Another illiberal trend is economic. It also precedes Covid-19. China in particular has presented its form of state capitalism as a countermodel to the West’s open and competitive market economies. In response, Western countries have started leaning toward more state intervention. 另一个反自由化趋势体现在经济上。它也是在疫情爆发之前出现的，特别是中国把它的国家资本主义形式作为西方开放和竞争性市场经济的反模式。作为回应，西方国家开始倾向于更多的国家干预。 The coronavirus has reinforced this change. Initially, the government interference was necessary. As the exogenous shock of the pandemic imposed bed rest on entire economies, only the state was left to pick up aggregate demand and prevent mass poverty. 冠状病毒加剧了这种变化。最初，政府的干预是必要的，由于流行病的外生冲击，使整个经济疲软不堪，只剩下国家来承担总需求，防止出现大规模贫困。 The question for 2021 is whether Leviathan will be able, or willing, to wean economies again from the huge stimulus packages, furlough programs, bankruptcy suspensions, subsidies and other interventions. German economists, for example, warn that their country could have 800,000 “zombie companies” next year. These are firms that probably should have died and exited the market for reasons unrelated to the pandemic but were kept alive artificially by government policy. 2021 年的问题是，利维坦是否有能力，或者说是否愿意，让经济再一次摆脱依靠那些庞大的刺激计划、休假计划、暂停破产、补贴和其他干预措施。例如，德国经济学家警告说，他们国家明年可能会出现 80 万家「僵尸公司」，这些公司就算没有疫情也会倒闭，但是却依靠政府的政策人为地延长了寿命。 Collectively, the world’s market economies have thus taken a big step in the general direction of central planning. As the coronavirus retreats next year, some governments will be tempted to extend this approach, also under the banner of “Green Deals” to fight climate change. 由此，世界上的市场经济国家都往政府计划的大方向上迈出了一大步。到明年疫情褪去，一些国家的政府定会把这种做法加以推广，但他们会打着「绿色交易」以应对气候变化的旗号。 Underneath these discrete policy areas, a more general suspicion has been spreading thatmarkets, capitalism, elections, rules and entire systems are all somehow rigged. Liberalism and individualism, according to this meme, are an ideology of the elites, by the elites, for the elites — a “liberalocracy,” as the author Patrick Deneen puts it in “Why Liberalism Failed.” 在这些离散的政策领域之下，一种更普遍的怀疑一直在蔓延：市场、资本主义、选举、规则和整个系统都被某种程度上操纵了。根据这个迷因，自由主义和个人主义是精英的意识形态，由精英所为，为精英服务——正如作家 Patrick Deneen 在《自由主义为何失败》中所说的那样，是一种「贵族自由主义」（liberalocracy）。 This perception is at first blush understandable. Many younger adults, the so-called Millennials, having been buffeted first by the financial crash of 2008 and now by Covid-19, don’t feel they’ve had a fair shot at building their lives and are increasingly embracing “socialism.” Black people and other members of minority groups suffer daily humiliations by racist cops or other bigots. Everywhere, the poor have been hit worst by Covid-19, both medically and economically. 这种看法乍一看是可以理解的。许多年轻人，也就是所谓的千禧一代，先是受到 2008 年金融风暴的冲击，现在又受到疫情的冲击，他们觉得自己没有公平的机会去建设自己的生活，然后逐渐开始接受「社会主义」；黑人和其他少数群体成员每天都在遭受有种族歧视的警察或其他种族歧视者的羞辱；无论在哪里，无论是在医疗上还是经济上，穷人受到疫情的冲击都是最严重的。 What has got lost in this atmosphere of crisis is that liberalism is not the source of these problems but rather the best starting point to find solutions to them. I’ve already tried to sketch two such approaches, to address climate change and inequality. Done right, a Universal Basic Income could be a reform that’s not only sensible but also liberal. 在这种危机气氛中，人们忽略了一点，那就是问题并不出在自由主义，反而自由主义是找到解决这些问题方法的最佳起点。我已试图勾勒出两种这样的方法，来解决气候变化和不平等问题。如果方法得当，全民基本收入可能是一项不仅合理而且自由的改革措施。 If there is a meta-crisis beyond all these problems, it may be what the historian Timothy Garton Ash calls a “disparity of esteem.” From the U.S. to Poland, societies have become polarized as people see one another less as individuals and more as representatives of rival groups and stereotypes: cosmopolitans versus bumpkins, “anywheres and somewheres,” the “woke” or the “deplorable,” those getting ahead and those falling behind. Sometimes the pain is less about feeling poor than about feeling unappreciated. 如果说在所有这些问题之上还有一个根本性危机的话，那可能就是历史学家 Timothy Garton Ash 所说的「自尊的差异」。从美国到波兰，人们不再把彼此看作一个个体，而更多地把彼此看作对立群体和刻板印象的代表，社会已经变得两极分化：城里人和乡下人的对立，「任何地方」和「有些地方」的对立，「清醒的」或「可悲的」对立，「领先的人」和「落后的人」的对立。有时，这种痛苦与其说是感到贫穷，不如说是感到不受重视。 This is the psychological landscape that populists have been exploiting with so much success in recent years. But they are peddlers of resentment, the political equivalent of snake oil. 这就是近年来民粹主义者利用的心理景观，这非常有用。但不要忘记他们是仇恨的传播者，在政治上骗人的万金油。 The tradition that genuinely esteems each individual irrespective of class, race, sex or zip code is classical liberalism, with its focus on personal liberty for all. It’s worth restating thismission in 2021. Freedom is like health: You don’t think about it until it’s gone. So let’s not wait that long. It’s been a bad year. Let’s make the liberal case for a better future. 古典自由主义的传统，是真正尊重每一个人，不分阶级、种族、性别或邮政编码，重点是：人人享有个人自由。在 2021 年，这一使命值得重申。自由就像健康一样，在它消失前，你根本不会想到它，所以我们不要等那么久。2020 非常糟糕，让我们面向更好的未来打上自由的印记。 大流行病必然会催生出大政府和各种管制，但如果紧急措施成为新的常态，自由必将消亡。 对个人自由来说，这是可怕的一年。我之所以这么说，还不是因为我碰巧发现自己又经历了一次封锁。 像战争或其他灾难一样，疫情也会改变事务的优先级。在 2020 年，个人自由似乎不那么重要，最为紧迫的似乎是公共卫生问题。令人惊讶的是，国家家长制似乎突然变得可以接受，或者至少是必要的。 但在这一过程中，疫情也成了各地已经不屑于自由的愤青和专制者试图将自由彻底埋葬的理想借口。随着 2021 年的到来，自由主义是否在全球范围内退缩？「自由主义」过时了吗？ 实即使在 2020 年初疫情还没发生时，前景也不是那么光明。2020 年 1 月，我写了一篇「自由主义宣言」，因为我担心古典自由主义正在过时，新的集体主义正在流行，疫情不过是加速了这一既有的趋势。 为避免混淆，首先让我在此阐明「自由」这个词的意思。这里的「自由」，与美国的左派、清醒或大政府没有任何关系，也与被讽刺的欧洲「新自由主义」和市场原教旨主义者无关。我们谈论的是一个古老的哲学概念，这里的「自由」将个人自由视为最高价值，同时充分认识到需要将这一原则与整个社会协调起来。 正因如此，自由主义者是可以偶尔忍受对自由的限制的。约翰·斯图尔特·密尔在其 1859 的论文《论自由》中定义了损害原则，即「人们若要干涉群体行动中任何个体的行动自由，无论干涉出自个人还是出自集体，其唯一正当的目的乃是保障自我不受伤害。」（注：此为三联书店 2019 年版《论自由》译文，译者孟凡礼） 因此，从本质上来讲，并不存在什么「不自由」。比如说，利用封锁减缓疫情传播，或要求我们在公共场合戴口罩；在经济混乱和困难的情况下，国家作为主要经济行为者暂时介入，向公司和人民支付费用，直到他们能够重新谋生，这也不必然是「不自由」。 但当这些措施被调整、扩大或滥用时，麻烦就开始了。最近几年，这个世界开始向极权主义倾斜。中国不需要借疫情去压迫维吾尔族人、镇压香港，卢卡申科也不需要借疫情去对白俄罗斯人施行暴政。但很多独裁者已经抓住了疫情这一借口，以打压其批评者，打压媒体自由，打压少数群体和其他他们不喜欢的人。 根据美国智库 Freedom House，今年民主和人权在 80 个国家出现了恶化。在津巴布韦，政府暴徒以维持治安封锁为名，逮捕、绑架、强奸或殴打反对派领导人、社会活动家和其他异议人士。这样的恶劣场景，从哈萨克斯坦到斯里兰卡、柬埔寨、危地马拉和许多其他地方的政权中都有出现。 即使在政府没有对人们进行身体上的暴政的地方，他们也会越来越多地对人们进行数字审查，或者以接触追踪为借口，建立新的监控工具。中国在这方面走得最远，在未经同意的情况下将生物统计学数据、金融数据和其他私密数据关联起来。即使是韩国和新加坡这样的民主地区，也有越来越多的基础设施通过轻轻地拨动开关，从高透明度变成了奥威尔式。 像德国或美国这样成熟的民主国家，制衡机制仍然强大，足以在可预见的未来防止这种荒诞情况发生。但在这些地方，作为任何自由社会的先决条件的民主和文明对话的气氛也已经恶化。 罪魁祸首是阴谋论者，他们总是在瘟疫时期兴风作浪。他们肆意滥用自由主义的核心原则：言论自由和集会自由的权利，来散布虚假信息和谎言。 自由主义者会首先捍卫这些人反对政府政策或以不同方式解释医学事实的权利。但当人们滥用他们的自由来质疑事实和歪曲真理时，就是在破坏我们的知识、心理和文化公域。 另一个反自由化趋势体现在经济上。它也是在疫情爆发之前出现的，特别是中国把它的国家资本主义形式作为西方开放和竞争性市场经济的反模式。作为回应，西方国家开始倾向于更多的国家干预。 冠状病毒加剧了这种变化。最初，政府的干预是必要的，由于流行病的外生冲击，使整个经济疲软不堪，只剩下国家来承担总需求，防止出现大规模贫困。 2021 年的问题是，利维坦是否有能力，或者说是否愿意，让经济再一次摆脱依靠那些庞大的刺激计划、休假计划、暂停破产、补贴和其他干预措施。例如，德国经济学家警告说，他们国家明年可能会出现 80 万家「僵尸公司」，这些公司就算没有疫情也会倒闭，但是却依靠政府的政策人为地延长了寿命。 由此，世界上的市场经济国家都往政府计划的大方向上迈出了一大步。到明年疫情褪去，一些国家的政府定会把这种做法加以推广，但他们会打着「绿色交易」以应对气候变化的旗号。 在这些离散的政策领域之下，一种更普遍的怀疑一直在蔓延：市场、资本主义、选举、规则和整个系统都被某种程度上操纵了。根据这个迷因，自由主义和个人主义是精英的意识形态，由精英所为，为精英服务——正如作家 Patrick Deneen 在《自由主义为何失败》中所说的那样，是一种「贵族自由主义」（liberalocracy）。 这种看法乍一看是可以理解的。许多年轻人，也就是所谓的千禧一代，先是受到 2008 年金融风暴的冲击，现在又受到疫情的冲击，他们觉得自己没有公平的机会去建设自己的生活，然后逐渐开始接受「社会主义」；黑人和其他少数群体成员每天都在遭受有种族歧视的警察或其他种族歧视者的羞辱；无论在哪里，无论是在医疗上还是经济上，穷人受到疫情的冲击都是最严重的。 在这种危机气氛中，人们忽略了一点，那就是问题并不出在自由主义，反而自由主义是找到解决这些问题方法的最佳起点。我已试图勾勒出两种这样的方法，来解决气候变化和不平等问题。如果方法得当，全民基本收入可能是一项不仅合理而且自由的改革措施。 如果说在所有这些问题之上还有一个根本性危机的话，那可能就是历史学家 Timothy Garton Ash 所说的「自尊的差异」。从美国到波兰，人们不再把彼此看作一个个体，而更多地把彼此看作对立群体和刻板印象的代表，社会已经变得两极分化：城里人和乡下人的对立，「任何地方」和「有些地方」的对立，「清醒的」或「可悲的」对立，「领先的人」和「落后的人」的对立。有时，这种痛苦与其说是感到贫穷，不如说是感到不受重视。 这就是近年来民粹主义者利用的心理景观，这非常有用。但不要忘记他们是仇恨的传播者，在政治上骗人的万金油。 古典自由主义的传统，是真正尊重每一个人，不分阶级、种族、性别或邮政编码，重点是：人人享有个人自由。在 2021 年，这一使命值得重申。自由就像健康一样，在它消失前，你根本不会想到它，所以我们不要等那么久。2020 非常糟糕，让我们面向更好的未来打上自由的印记。 A pandemic is by necessity a time for restrictions and Big Government. But if emergency measures become the new normal, liberty dies. It’s been a terrible year for personal freedom. And I’m not just saying that because I happen to find myself in yet another lockdown. Like war or other disasters, a pandemic shifts priorities. In 2020, individual liberty seemed less important and public health appeared most urgent. State paternalism suddenly looked surprisingly acceptable, or at least necessary. But along the way, Covid-19 also became an ideal pretext for cynics and autocrats everywhere who already disdained liberty to try to bury it altogether. As 2021 dawns, is freedom in global retreat? Is “liberalism” passé? The outlook wasn’t all that bright even at the start of 2020. In January, I penned a “liberal manifesto” because I feared that classical liberalism was going out of fashion and a new collectivism was becoming vogue. Covid-19 has accelerated that preexisting trend. To avoid confusion, let’s be clear about the word liberal here. It has nothing to do with its American meaning of lefty, woke or big government; nor with its European caricature as “neoliberal” and market fundamentalist. We’re talking instead about a venerable philosophy that regards individual freedom as the highest value while fully recognizing the need to harmonize this principle with society as a whole. For that reason, liberalism can occasionally live with restrictions on liberty. The harm principle, as defined in 1859 by John Stuart Mill in his treatise “On Liberty,” says that “the only purpose for which power can be rightfully exercised over any member of a civilized community, against his will, is to prevent harm to others.” So there’s nothing inherently illiberal about, say, a lockdown to slow the spread of Covid-19. Or about a regulation that requires us to wear masks in public. Nor is it automatically illiberal for the state, in a situation of economic disruption and distress, to step in temporarily as the primary economic actor, paying firms and people until they can earn their livelihoods again. The trouble starts when these measures are adapted, extended or abused. The world was already tilting toward authoritarianism in recent years. China didn’t need Covid-19 to oppress the Uighurs or clamp down on Hong Kong, nor did Alexander Lukashenko need it to tyrannize Belarussians. But many autocrats have seized on the coronavirus as another excuse to crack down on their critics, the free press, minority populations and others they don’t like. Democracy and human rights have deteriorated in 80 countries this year, according to Freedom House, an American think tank. In Zimbabwe, government thugs have, in the name of policing lockdown infractions, arrested, abducted, raped or assaulted opposition leaders, activists and other dissenters. Authorities from Kazakhstan to Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Guatemala and many other places have been almost as bad. Even where governments don’t physically tyrannize people, they increasingly censor them digitally or, under the pretext of contact tracing, build new surveillance tools. China has gone furthest, by connecting biometric, financial and other intimate information about citizens without their assent. Even democratic societies such as South Korea and Singapore increasingly have an infrastructure they could turn from transparent to Orwellian with the flick of a switch. In mature democracies such as Germany or the U.S., checks and balances remain robust enough to prevent such dystopias for the foreseeable future. But there too the climate for democratic and civilized discourse, the precondition for any liberal society, has deteriorated. The main culprits are conspiracy theorists, who always thrive in times of plague. They wantonly abuse the right to free speech and assembly — core principles of liberalism — to spread disinformation and lies. Liberals will be the first to defend these people’s right to disagree with government policies or to interpret medical facts differently. But when people misuse their own liberty to impugn facts and pervert truth they are vandalizing our intellectual, psychological and cultural commons. Another illiberal trend is economic. It also precedes Covid-19. China in particular has presented its form of state capitalism as a countermodel to the West’s open and competitive market economies. In response, Western countries have started leaning toward more state intervention. The coronavirus has reinforced this change. Initially, the government interference was necessary. As the exogenous shock of the pandemic imposed bed rest on entire economies, only the state was left to pick up aggregate demand and prevent mass poverty. The question for 2021 is whether Leviathan will be able, or willing, to wean economies again from the huge stimulus packages, furlough programs, bankruptcy suspensions, subsidies and other interventions. German economists, for example, warn that their country could have 800,000 “zombie companies” next year. These are firms that probably should have died and exited the market for reasons unrelated to the pandemic but were kept alive artificially by government policy. Collectively, the world’s market economies have thus taken a big step in the general direction of central planning. As the coronavirus retreats next year, some governments will be tempted to extend this approach, also under the banner of “Green Deals” to fight climate change. Underneath these discrete policy areas, a more general suspicion has been spreading thatmarkets, capitalism, elections, rules and entire systems are all somehow rigged. Liberalism and individualism, according to this meme, are an ideology of the elites, by the elites, for the elites — a “liberalocracy,” as the author Patrick Deneen puts it in “Why Liberalism Failed.” This perception is at first blush understandable. Many younger adults, the so-called Millennials, having been buffeted first by the financial crash of 2008 and now by Covid-19, don’t feel they’ve had a fair shot at building their lives and are increasingly embracing “socialism.” Black people and other members of minority groups suffer daily humiliations by racist cops or other bigots. Everywhere, the poor have been hit worst by Covid-19, both medically and economically. What has got lost in this atmosphere of crisis is that liberalism is not the source of these problems but rather the best starting point to find solutions to them. I’ve already tried to sketch two such approaches, to address climate change and inequality. Done right, a Universal Basic Income could be a reform that’s not only sensible but also liberal. If there is a meta-crisis beyond all these problems, it may be what the historian Timothy Garton Ash calls a “disparity of esteem.” From the U.S. to Poland, societies have become polarized as people see one another less as individuals and more as representatives of rival groups and stereotypes: cosmopolitans versus bumpkins, “anywheres and somewheres,” the “woke” or the “deplorable,” those getting ahead and those falling behind. Sometimes the pain is less about feeling poor than about feeling unappreciated. This is the psychological landscape that populists have been exploiting with so much success in recent years. But they are peddlers of resentment, the political equivalent of snake oil. The tradition that genuinely esteems each individual irrespective of class, race, sex or zip code is classical liberalism, with its focus on personal liberty for all. It’s worth restating thismission in 2021. Freedom is like health: You don’t think about it until it’s gone. So let’s not wait that long. It’s been a bad year. posts.title: Inside the Dystopian, Post-Lockdown World of Wuhan
posts.text: 为什么选这篇文章 这篇文章是 4 月 27 日《彭博商业周刊》（Bloomberg Businessweek）的头条文章。这篇文章原文就有 3700 多词，译文更是接近 6400 个汉字，我从来没有翻译过这么长的文章。但我觉得这是一篇非常有深度的文章，兼具事实陈述和人文思考，非常值得一读。 中英双语 中文 英文 The first epicenter is coming back to life, but not as anyone knew it.疫情的爆发地解封了，但和人们所知道的似乎有偏差。 Every workday at Lenovo’s tablet and phone factory on the outskirts of Wuhan, arriving employees report to a supervisor for the first of at least four temperature checks. The results are fed into a data collection system designed by staff. Anyone above 37.3C (99.1F) is automatically flagged, triggering an investigation by an in-house “anti-virus task force.” 联想的武汉工厂位于市郊，前来上班的员工们都需要将体温检测的结果汇报给上级，这样的汇报每天至少需要进行四次。他们的体温检测数据将被录入工厂员工设计的系统。体温高于 37.3 摄氏度的员工将会被自动标记，之后他们会成为「疫情防控小组」调查的对象。 Daily routines at the facility, which reopened on March 28 after stopping for over two months because of the coronavirus pandemic that began in this central Chinese city, have been entirely reengineered to minimize the risk of infection. Before returning to the site, staff members had to be tested both for the virus and for antibodies that indicate past illness, and they had to wait for their results in isolation at a dedicated dormitory. Once cleared, they returned to work to find the capacity of meeting rooms built for six reduced to three and the formerly communal cafeteria tables partitioned off by vertical barriers covered in reminders to avoid conversation. Signs everywhere indicate when areas were last disinfected, and robots are deployed wherever possible to transport supplies, so as to reduce the number of people moving from place to place. Elevators, too, are an artifact of the Before Times; everyone now has to take the stairs, keeping their distance from others all the way. 由于疫情关闭了两个月的这座工厂终于在 3 月 28 日复工，工厂方重新设计了每日例行检查程序，以减少感染的风险。在复工前，工作人员必须先进行病毒和抗体的检测，员工们需要在专门的宿舍隔离等待结果。当员工们检测无异常，并回到工作岗位的时候，他们会发现，可容纳 6 人的会议室如今只能坐 3 人，食堂里的餐桌被栅栏隔开，上面贴满了提醒语，提醒人们不要交谈。所有的地方都有指示牌，指示牌上标明了上一次该处进行消毒的时间；为了防止人们四处走动，工厂使用机器人运送所有能用其运送的物资。电梯成为了一件属于疫情前的艺术品，因为如今人们得爬楼梯以保持人与人之间的距离。 Presiding over all these measures one Sunday in mid-April was Qi Yue, head of Wuhan operations for Beijing-based Lenovo Group Ltd. Qi, who’s 48, with closely cropped hair and a sturdy frame, had been visiting his hometown of Tianjin, in China’s north, when the government sealed off Wuhan from the rest of the country on Jan. 23. It had taken him until Feb. 9 to get home—and he was only able to make it by buying a train ticket to Changsha, farther down the line, and begging the crew to let him get off in Wuhan. His job was now to bring the factory slowly back to life while emphasizing vigilance. Compared with keeping the virus out of the plant, he said, “how much production we can deliver comes second.” 以上所有的决策，都是联想集团武汉工厂负责人齐岳在四月中旬的一个下午想出来的。今年 48 岁的齐岳头发有些散乱，但身体还不错。今年 1 月 23 日武汉政府宣布封城时，他还在他的老家天津。23. 疫情使得他在天津停留到了 2 月 9 日才回到武汉，而且他只能买到去长沙的票。长沙是武汉站的下一站，他向列车工作人员求情才得以在武汉提前下车。他现在的工作主要是在确保安全的前提下缓慢复工。他说，与不让病毒进入工厂相比，「产量倒是其次。」 Qi is one of millions of people in Wuhan trying to figure out what economic and social life looks like after the worst pandemic in a century. In some respects they’re in a decent position. In some respects they’re in a decent position. The outbreak in Hubei province peaked in mid-February, and according to official statistics there are now almost no new infections occurring (though other governments have cast doubt on China’s figures). But scientists warn that the novel coronavirus is stealthy and robust, and a resurgence is still possible until there’s a reliable vaccine. How to balance that risk against the need to reignite an industrial hub of more than 10 million people is a formidable dilemma—one governments around the world will soon be facing. So far, Wuhan’s answer has been to create a version of normal that would appear utterly alien to people in London, Milan, or New York—at least for the moment. While daily routines have largely resumed, there remain significant restrictions on a huge range of activities, from funerals to hosting visitors at home. Bolstered by China’s powerful surveillance state, even the simplest interactions are mediated by a vast infrastructure of public and private monitoring intended to ensure that no infection goes undetected for more than a few hours. But inasmuch as citizens can return to living as they did before January, it’s not clear, after what they’ve endured, that they really want to. Shopping malls and department stores are open again, but largely empty. The same is true of restaurants; people are ordering in instead. The subway is quiet, but autos are selling: If being stuck in traffic is annoying, at least it’s socially distanced. Qi figures he’s probably on the right side of this economic rebalancing. Tablets are in high demand as schools around the world switch to remote learning, and companies contemplating a work-from-home future aren’t likely to skimp on technology budgets. Since restarting operations, he’s hired more than 1,000 workers, bringing the on-site total above 10,000, and production lines are running at full capacity. He said he was painfully aware, however, of how quickly work would stop if even one employee contracted the virus. “In my meetings with my staff I always tell them, ‘No loosening up, no loosening up.’ We can’t allow any accidents.” More than 80% of China’s almost 84,000 confirmed cases of Covid-19, and more than 95% of the roughly 4,600 confirmed deaths, have been in Hubei, of which Wuhan is the capital and largest city. Controlling the outbreak there, after a series of mistakes by President Xi Jinping’s government, which initially downplayed the risk of human-to-human transmission and failed to prevent widespread infection of medical personnel, required a herculean effort. More than 40,000 doctors and other medical staff were dispatched from other regions to reinforce existing facilities and operate field hospitals built in the space of 10 days, and car and electronics companies were pressed into making protective gear. People suspected of having the disease were required to move into dormitories and hotels repurposed as isolation facilities, and allowed to go home only after they’d been declared infection-free. Hubei was the last region of China to resume daily life, with curbs on movement lifted progressively from late March until April 8, more than three months after the epidemic began. The government presented the moment as a decisive victory—part of a comprehensive effort to rewrite the narrative of the virus as a Communist Party triumph, in contrast to its catastrophic spread in Western democracies. Late on the night of April 7, crowds began arriving at Wuchang station, one of three large railway hubs in Wuhan. The first outbound train in weeks, to Guangzhou, was scheduled to leave at 12:50 a.m., followed by a dense schedule of departures to many of China’s major cities. (Wuhan’s position at the junction of several major rail and road routes, along with its industrial heft, has invited frequent comparisons to Chicago.) Police in black uniforms and medical masks seemed to be everywhere. “Scan your code!” they shouted at travelers approaching the departure gates. The public-private “health code” system that China developed to manage Covid-19, hosted on the Alipay and WeChat apps but deeply linked with the government, assigns one of three viral risk statuses—red, yellow, or green—to every citizen. It’s a powerful tool with clear potential for abuse. A green QR code, which denotes a low risk of having the virus, is the general default, while coming into contact with an infected person can trigger a yellow code and a mandatory quarantine. Red is for a likely or confirmed case. Travel between cities requires a green code, and while Zeng Xiao, 22, had hers and felt fine, she was nervous about making her train. “There’s still a chance I’ll be stopped if my temperature is too high,” she said as she neared the departure zone. Before going to the station, Zeng had checked repeatedly for a fever, worried that being even a little bit warm would prevent her from getting to Guangzhou, where she works as a teacher. “I haven’t seen my cat in almost three months,” she said. She didn’t have to worry. Her temperature scan was normal, and she was soon able to board her train south. Another passenger leaving on the first day, Qin Xin’an, 26, had been stranded since the lockdown began. He’d been on vacation in Wuhan when Hubei was cut off, and no amount of pleading with officials could get him on a train out. By mid-February he was living off online loans. “I was eating instant noodles for every meal,” he said. He ended up getting a bed in an austere dormitory constructed by the local government for people who couldn’t leave. He also found work doing odd jobs at Leishenshan Hospital, one of the temporary infirmaries built to handle coronavirus patients. He’d lost his regular job, at a company in Jiangsu province that makes robots, because he couldn’t get back, and was now headed to Guangdong to look for another one and see his family. He hadn’t told his parents where he’d been all this time; as far as they knew, he was away working. “I will not tell them I was in Wuhan,” Qin said. When dawn broke, Wuhan came cautiously back to life. Hairdressers were some of the first businesses to fill up. The roads were noticeably busier, and workers flowed back into office towers in the city center. But these new freedoms felt distinctly provisional. At the entrance to every mall or public building, guards stood sentry with temperature scanners, ready to turn away anyone whose reading was too high. Green codes, required even to ride the subway, have become the city’s most precious possession, and one that’s easy to lose. Merely visiting a building around the same time as a person later found to be infected can turn them yellow. And apartment compounds still reserve the right to bar residents from leaving if cases are reported there, as they did during the lockdown. Even in the first city to confront the virus, following a containment effort as intense as any in the history of public health, the danger remains acute. “Asymptomatic cases and imported cases are still risks,” Wang Xinghuan, the president of one of the city’s major hospitals and of the Leishenshan facility, told reporters at a press conference before the latter’s closing. And many residents are still susceptible. Wang’s hospital gave antibody tests to all 3,600 of its staff, and fewer than 3% came back positive—a result that shows “there’s no herd immunity in Wuhan.” There’s only one way to durably protect the population, he said: a vaccine. Wuhan’s businesses are nevertheless hoping for a safe but speedy return to conspicuous consumption. In the days before the city fully reopened for business, the sales team at a local Audi dealership gathered for their daily meeting. The 20 or so salespeople were all dressed in dark suits and face masks, standing well over a meter apart in neat columns. As a manager briefed them on the day’s plans, a colleague made his way through the group, spraying everyone with disinfectant as they spun around to ensure full coverage. “Customers may not be kind enough to tell you if they don’t feel well, so try not to bring them into the store,” the manager said. “Just talk to them at the entrance if possible.” After reopening on March 23, the dealership had been selling about seven cars per day, on pace with last year despite all the restrictions. Most were relatively low-end vehicles, such as the A3, which retails for about 200,000 yuan ($28,000)—the kind of car often bought by families to complement a bigger, fancier model. “People are not willing to take public transport in Wuhan,” said the marketing director, who asked to be identified by only his surname, Pan. “And they don’t dare commute by Didi”—the ubiquitous ride-hailing app. The focus now, Pan said, was on following up with people who’d expressed interest in an Audi in the past but hadn’t bought one. They might be ready to bite. The dealership was looking to expand its current staff of about 150, and employees would soon receive the pay they’d missed during the lockdown. Another salesperson added, “It’s like a boom.” For many other businesses in Wuhan, though, it’s anything but. Benny Xiao is director of international operations at Wuhan Boyuan Paper & Plastic Co., which produces the kinds of unremarkable but essential goods that still form the backbone of Chinese industry. In his case, they’re disposable cups, which Boyuan sells to U.S. airlines and Japanese retailers, among other clients. Xiao works from an office inside a dilapidated residential compound, and, wearing a battered gray blazer over a green button-down, he didn’t quite look the part of an international dealmaker. But he beamed with pride as he showed off a glass cabinet in his office stuffed with examples of his craft, from thin plastic vessels for economy-class soda to a sturdy tumbler he’d tried, unsuccessfully, to sell to Starbucks Corp. The first months of the pandemic were challenging for Xiao, as they were for everyone in Wuhan. His wife, now retired, spent her career as a doctor at Xiehe Hospital, one of the first to report cases of what was later identified as the coronavirus, and she’d begun hearing from colleagues in mid-January about the impending crisis. Sick residents “were lining up outside Xiehe at 10 p.m. in the freezing cold,” many of them “older people who could barely make it,” Xiao recalled. “Patients were really desperately looking for help.” He and his wife had stocked up on food before the lockdown began, but three weeks in they started to run out. Unlike in Europe and the U.S., Wuhan’s containment measures made it difficult for people to leave their buildings, even to buy groceries, forcing them to rely on delivery apps, government drop-offs, and neighbors who wrangled permission to go out. At one point, Xiao had to spend 26 yuan (almost $4) for a single cabbage, more than triple the usual price. Some of the vegetables provided by local officials were barely edible. He returned in late March to a company in severe trouble. Orders in the first half of the year were headed for a 50% drop, with demand from food deliveries failing to offset the calamitous decline in air travel. The government had made some financial help available, but Xiao wasn’t sure he’d be able to avoid layoffs. “Back in January and February, I was expecting things to come back to normal in April,” he said. Instead, “I was just calling the bank this morning to tell them that I can’t repay the interest on our loan.” For a country that’s experienced an essentially uninterrupted boom throughout the living memory of anyone younger than 50, broad-based economic pain is deeply unfamiliar. The Chinese economy shrank 6.8% in the first quarter of the year, and the International Monetary Fund estimates it will grow just 1.2% in 2020, the worst performance since 1976. Urban unemployment, a widely scrutinized indicator of overall joblessness, rose to a record 6.2% in February before pulling back slightly in March. And it’s not clear what China’s business model will look like in a world where Europe, the U.S., and other key markets for its goods are flirting with a depression. Xiao is 64, part of a Chinese generation that had seen more than its share of history even before the coronavirus emerged. But he struggled to recall anything in his experience that was more dramatic, save perhaps the famine of the Great Leap Forward, when he was a young child. “This is the biggest crisis of my lifetime,” he said. The entrance to Wuhan’s Biandanshan Cemetery is marked by an impressive stone gate with a pagoda-style roof and a frieze of a ferocious-looking dragon. But in recent weeks, it’s been partly hidden behind a series of bright yellow crowd control barriers surrounded by temporary metal fencing and watched carefully by police. Almost no one is permitted to enter until April 30, and even then access is likely to be strictly controlled. Officially, no patients in Wuhan are still dying from Covid-19, but the treatment of those who did pass away remains an extremely sensitive subject. On Tomb-Sweeping Day in early April, when Chinese families traditionally gather to pay respects to their ancestors, Wuhan’s cemeteries were kept closed. Funerals have been banned until at least the end of the month, and family members of the dead have reported pressure from government officials to mourn quickly and quietly. According to the government, these measures are purely a matter of public health, because family gatherings are a potential vector for infection. But the restrictions also help Beijing avoid having funerals become a venue for people to vent anger about how the epidemic was handled, or to ask uncomfortable questions about subjects such as China’s true death toll. Whatever the reasons for maintaining the ban, some mental health providers in Wuhan have expressed fears that the inability to properly mourn loved ones will have deep and enduring psychological consequences. The city’s residents were the first to undergo the unprecedented social shutdown that’s been repeated around the world, and it seems certain to mark many of them for a long time, especially if it’s compounded by a prolonged economic slump. Yao Jun is among those struggling to move on. The petite 50-year-old is the founder and general manager of Wuhan Welhel Photoelectric Co., a manufacturer of welding helmets and protective masks that exports to France, Germany, and the U.S. She came back to work on March 13 after wading through approvals from four layers of government, including her local neighborhood committee, which took 15 days to assess Welhel’s ability to prevent infections. “We can’t afford to have a single one,” Yao said in an interview at her factory. Every day the production line can run is crucial: Welhel was trying to catch up on orders it hadn’t been able to complete in the first few months of the year, even as Yao wasn’t sure her customers in locked-down overseas markets would be able to take the deliveries. She had no idea when more business would come in, given what’s happening to the global economy. Despite the uncertainties, she was trying to focus on work rather than what the city had just gone through. “I can’t see news about medical workers without crying,” Yao said, choking back tears and rubbing a jade keychain attached to her phone. She was having trouble sleeping, as she turned over the stories of doctors and nurses who’d succumbed to Covid-19 again and again in her head: “I don’t know these people, but if someone tells me what happened to them, it’s devastating. These deaths aren’t just numbers or strange names to me. They’re vivid lives.” She believed that many of her neighbors and colleagues were experiencing similar emotions but might not be willing or able to talk about them. “Many other people are traumatized but can’t recognize the problem or express their feelings,” she said. The pandemic was causing Yao to rethink her life. She spent almost half of last year on the road, often visiting clients overseas. Now, she said, she wanted to spend much more time at home, keeping her family close. Her son was supposed to return to Australia for university in February, but he was unable to get there, for obvious reasons. Yao didn’t want him to go back. Even after seemingly world-shattering events, human behavior has a way of reverting to the mean. In the weeks after Sept. 11, commentators predicted the end of globalization, of the skyscraper, of irony—which all, needless to say, persisted. Within a couple of years of the global financial crisis, banks and homebuyers were back to arranging risky mortgages, and the very wealthy were back to, and then well beyond, pre-2008 levels of excess. It’s reasonable to think this time will be different. Hardly anyone alive today has endured a pandemic this severe, and the basic problem it’s created—that anyone, whether friend, family, or stranger, might be a vector for lethal infection—is uniquely corrosive to the daily interactions that keep countries and economies going. An effective vaccine could be at least a year off, and given what the world has learned about how quickly a novel pathogen can shut everything down, even that might not return things to the way they were. Wuhan was the first place to traverse both sides of the Covid-19 curve, and how it changes, or doesn’t, in the disease’s aftermath will say a lot to the rest of us. Many of the city’s methods won’t be universally applicable. Few other governments could assemble the all-seeing anti-viral surveillance China is trying to put in place, even if they wanted to. Fewer still, probably, have populations that would tolerate it. But whatever the tactics, the key lesson of Wuhan could be that the price of beating the virus is never-ending vigilance and a reordering of priorities that will be hard for many to accept. At a Starbucks in one of Wuhan’s fancier shopping districts, Ma Renren, a 32-year-old entrepreneur who runs a small marketing agency, talked about how he was sorting out these questions for himself. The store was open but only serving drinks to go, with customers permitted to sit at outdoor tables. Security guards were keeping a close eye on things, interrupting conversations to tell patrons to keep their masks on between sips and not sit too close together. Ma, who was wearing fashionably oversize glasses, a black baseball cap, and—of course—a light blue medical mask, had gone to stay at his parents’ apartment on Jan. 24, intending to help take care of them. But soon he began to suspect that he might be sick. It was a time of greatly heightened emotion: No one knew the true fatality rate, and people in Wuhan were seeing reports on social media of appalling conditions in overwhelmed hospitals. “I wrote my last words one night and decided to say farewell to my parents and go to the hospital alone the next morning,” Ma recalled. “I knew that if I went, I couldn’t necessarily expect to come back.” He changed his mind at the last minute and eventually felt better, though the psychological effects lingered. He began having panic attacks, his breath short and his heart pounding. After looking up the symptoms online, he concluded that he was experiencing post-traumatic stress. Experiences like his, Ma thought, would make many people more introspective and more focused on those closest to them. “We will put aside more time for ourselves and our families” and for the other relationships that seemed truly worth holding on to during the crisis, he said. “Misfortune tests the sincerity of friendship.” Ma was now trying to get his company back on its feet. The government had recently sent him a tax rebate as part of its stimulus measures, but this would help only so much. Tourism has collapsed, and few potential clients have much money for promotion. “There’s nothing to do but move on,” he said. Ma had, inevitably, lowered his ambitions, and for the time being he was all right with that. “We worked nonstop for years, chasing every opportunity,” he said. Now, “everyone I know has one goal for 2020. posts.title: 周年纪念 |“二十之惑”
posts.text: Photo by Angèle Kamp on Unsplash 这个网站是我送给自己的 20 岁生日礼物，今天则是这个网站建立一周年的日子。尽管这之中遇到了一点瓶颈（删除了一堆我觉得很烂的文章），但我这个在家人口中「没有恒心」的人，能在这个事情上坚持一年，也算是个小小的奇迹。 这个网站给我带来了很大的改变。当然，我说的这种改变并不是因为我写的文章太好而出名了——我写的文章根本没几个人看。所以改变更多的还是来源于我在这里写文章时产生的某种内省。我每年某个时候都会产生一种「我今年变化真大啊」的感受，而我建立网站后的这一年，带给我的改变是前几年前所未有的。因为在此之前，我从未想过去回答一些所谓「大问题」，但如今我似乎非常急迫地想要去回答这个问 ­ 题：我究竟要成为一个什么样的人？ 我们经常被教育「要努力适应社会」，但这句话似乎逐渐被定义为「顺应社会」了：我们接受着各种各样的游戏规则，接受着各种各样系统的支配，接受着各种各样把以上的糟糕秩序合理化的说辞——譬如多元主义、社会生物学。在此过程中，我们的信念和价值逐渐变得虚无，理想主义遭到唾弃，而那些口口声声说着反对资本主义的人，恰恰是那些资本主义文化中陷入得最深的人。 当下的环境确实风高浪急，但这并不意味着我应该采用某种独善其身的方式生活，也不意味着我应该去接受老掉牙心灵鸡汤所鼓吹的那种「活出自我」，我更愿意退一步，在建构某种具体的「我要成为的人」之前，先去审视自己生活的真实性。 今年臭名昭著的《后浪》，有句话说「现在的年轻人，早早就进入了不惑之年」。同为年轻人（如果我这个年纪还算年轻的话），我却完全不希望成为《后浪》里的「不惑」之人。当然《后浪》显然曲解了《论语》里讲的「不惑」的含义，但顺着视频的字面意思，「不惑」确实可以反映出我们这一代人的一些问题，也就是「没有疑惑」。 「没有疑惑」难道不是件好事吗？我们以前总是认为知识越多越好，问题越少越好，如今我身边的很多同龄人似乎就就到了某种这种博学的境界：中美之争、经济原理、地缘政治、少数平权……他们谈这些话题时似乎都充满自信，头头是道，这是非常奇怪的。与其相比，我在这里写的文章大多数都是我在一些非常细微的地方的想法，我很少去评判一些宏观事件的是非曲直——我甚至根本不关心这些，我只关心我们是如何被这些事件塑造的，最终还是指向个人的内省。 如果说「不惑」究竟给我们这代人带来了什么，我会认为其带来的是一种对于虚无的掩盖。谈论宏观大事背后的是非曲直，实际上是在逃避属于自身的那些微观问题，同样，那些说「赚钱最重要」、「先有面包，后有理想」的人，实际上则是用对具体的物质的追求掩盖理想的空虚，我们总以为财富自由后，理想的实现就是水到渠成的事，但「先有面包，后有理想」这句话本身就说明了追求理想就是比追求物质要困难——或者根本就没有什么理想，理想只是一个追求物质的漂亮借口而已。 所以我要收回自己之前对于「现实」的崇拜，重新去审视理想。「认清现实」并不有助于通达良好生活，只有助于我们对理想望而却步，而且我们就是在不断「认清现实」的过程中被逐渐磨平棱角，不断丧失对于「追求」本身的动力的。所以如果让我给自己设定一个目标，我会想成为一个「圆滑当道世界的尖锐异类」，但尖锐并不是为了去对抗圆滑，而是像植物的尖刺那样保护自己的「完整性」。 所以相比起大家的「不惑」，我感觉自己所疑惑的事情还多的很，值得寻求答案的问题还有很多，值得追求的非物质的理想也有很多，不必早早地把自己交给「现实」，永远「尖锐」，永远保持骄傲。

posts.title: 2020 年度总结 |“资本”竟是我们自己
posts.text: Photo by Jp Valery on Unsplash 关于年度总结 理论上来说，2020 的年度总结应该在 2021 年到来前写完。但因为经历了一些事情，整个人散漫了很长一段时间，所以拖到了现在。不过，从农历来看，现在其实还是 2020 年，所以在下个月 12 日前，我写的还是能算作 2020 年度总结的：）。 2020 年是互联网企业出事颇为频繁的一年。倒也不全是因为疫情，就我国这种互联网企业发展的架势，这一天迟早会来，疫情只是让各种尚未成熟的互联网服务及其背后的体系被提前推上舞台了中央。从 996 事件，到小黄车押金、蛋壳公寓爆雷、被困在系统里的外卖小哥、双十一快递罢工，然后到 2021 年年初的外卖小哥猝死、拼多多加班过劳死，这些事件背后的行业，是随着我国这几年互联网成长起来的，我们这代人亲眼见证了它们从无到有到繁荣兴盛的过程。 但同样是我们这代人，在面对这些互联网展现出来的问题时，却倾向于非常简单地进行归因。在上述事件的公共舆论中，「资本」和「资本家」这个词往往高频率地出现，只要大公司出了什么问题，大家就开始搬运马克思批判资本家的话语，开始谴责资本主义的邪恶。不要误会我，我并没有要否定马克思及其观点，资本主义确实是很糟糕的秩序，但是把原因归结到一两个「资本家」身上甚至是「资本」这个非实体之上，未免有些虚空打靶，而且单纯地批判也解决不了任何问题。 法律有用吗？当然有用。不过我们也必须要明白，法律不是自动机，并不是一出问题，法律马上就能出来维持秩序，将社会调回到某种良好状态。事物的背后往往非常复杂，并不是单靠某部法律制定就能立马解决的。 回顾这些事件，我们在面对这些事件的时候，究竟忽略了什么？我们忽略了我们自己。我们这一代人太崇拜互联网了，认为互联网带来的所有便利都是理所当然的，我们之所以能享受到便捷的外卖、不断提速的快递、廉价的商品，全部都是得益于互联网。 但是互联网说到底还是用来达成目的的技术，它如何发挥作用，发挥什么样的作用，最终还是取决于背后使用这套技术的人。今天我们能享受到所谓「便利」、「实惠」的互联网产品，并不是因为互联网，而是互联网背后活生生的人。而我想说的是，正是在技术的遮蔽下，我们忽略了我们享受便利的背后究竟是什么。 互联网给我们带来了两种可能性：一是低廉的价格，便宜的「百亿补贴」商品、大额的外卖满减券、十元包月的共享单车，这些似乎都让我们用便宜很多的价格购买到商品；二是财富的增殖，主要是各种互联网金融产品，各种抓住「风口」的创业机会。 巧合的是，互联网给我们带来的这些可能性，实际上本来就是企业运营的目标。企业也像我们一样，期望着原材料的成本一降再降、期望着财报越来越好看、期望着企业管理系统运作效率越来越高，这看上去并没有什么不对的地方。企业与个人的需求在互联网上达成一致，似乎也是个不错的结果。 但是这两种可能性本身就是有矛盾的。也就是说并没有某种完美的少花钱多办事的运行模式，一旦我们想要同时达成这两项目标，总会产生其他的问题。在某些方面，可能表现为虚拟和现实的差异（譬如造假、货不对板）；在另一些方面，则是链条中的一些人会受到压榨。在当下，后者比前者其实更为常见，而互联网的存在使这种压榨更为隐形，因为你在互联网上见不到活生生的人，见不到你的几次点击会给其他人带来什么样的影响。 举个例子，我们想要在保证质量的情况下，让外卖更加便宜快捷有错吗？似乎没有。但是我们需要回过头，看看当外卖真的更加便宜快捷时究竟发生了什么。其实只需要一个简单的前提，那就是「钱不会凭空变出来」，那么在这一前提下，外卖价格下降，肯定是因为成本下降。此时，有两种方案降低成本：商家降低成本，这会导致货不对板；平台降低成本，结果是员工薪资降低或者一个人干多个人的活；配送端降低成本，结果是外卖送餐员必须一次性接多单，而这又势必会延长配送时间，而若是超过了规定的配送时间，用户会不快，平台也会克扣外卖送餐员的报酬，最后结果自不必多说，就是最近的新闻。 当然，到这里你可能会反驳说，互联网公司员工工资本来就高，也有月入过万的外卖送餐员，外卖送餐员本来素质就不高有工作就不错了云云。巧了，企业也是这么想的，所以两端都会认为，如果链条两端都能受益，那么中间层成为代价可以是理所当然的。 拼多多也是一样，我们要求商品的价格更低有错吗？似乎没有，但是「百亿补贴」的钱不是风刮来的，是投资者往这个公司投的钱。而只有拼多多的财报变得好看，股价才能上涨，才有更多投资人往里继续投钱。要想财报好看，就必须提升利润，方法同样也是降低成本或者提高价格。所以一方面，你可以看到当下的电商游戏规则愈发复杂，抢红包、挣积分、邀请人助力……越难懂、越费时间越好，反正就是要不断提高消费者的成本，变相「涨价」；另一方面，其又在自身管理上开刀，无视劳动法的加班、各种残酷的用人制度，目的也是降低人力成本。所以拼多多在其声明中说： 这不是资本的问题，这是社会的问题。 这很令人惊讶吗？要说什么东西真正令人惊讶，那就是面对一点利益而不顾任何代价，抛弃同理心的我们自己。这些公司用红包、满减这些方式问我们：你们真的可以为了这点利益什么都不管吗？很遗憾，回答是：是的，你快拿来，别磨磨唧唧的。 所以我们在说资本坏的时候，我们究竟在说什么？我们是在批判黄峥、马云这些资本家吗？我们是在谴责互联网这套「吃人」的体系吗？说到底，如果「资本」真的可以被还原为某种物质实体，那么肯定是每一个希望价格无限低、财富永续增长、永远保持高效的我们自己。 所以当我们一次次面对这样的事件时，期望系统本身做出改变，无疑是一种见效非常慢，且效果也非常差的方法。去年《外卖骑手，困在系统里》的报道出来后，我们的第一反应是呼吁两家大公司对派单系统和计算系统作出改变，把我们自己的责任撇得干干净净，甚至还去评判哪家拿出的改变方案更好（或者说，把我们的责任撇得更干净）。当然系统问题很大，到现在我也没见到饿了么「愿意等五分钟」的按钮上线，美团上的预计送达时间也没见增加，这之中确实有虚伪性。但是比起系统，从使用系统的我们开始，无疑是更有效且更直接的，我们的欲望一天不降，系统也只会变着花样对链条中间进行挤压。 到这里，解决方案非常简单，那就是我们每个人拒绝这些看似廉价便利的工具，不点外卖、不用拼多多、不参与「薅羊毛」，拒绝所有用廉价和便捷包装的糖衣炮弹。当然我知道这很难实现，我也坦率地说我很难达成，但认识到这一点，我们至少需要进行一些努力，不说彻底抛弃，至少要认识到这之中我们扮演的重要角色，至少在点外卖之前问问自己「我这外卖是非点不可吗」，在拼多多下单时思考「这个商品本身是我应该享受的吗」。 如果这都有困难，还有一个妥协较少的方案，不过听上去挺令人不快的：不因为外卖不能送到门口、餐冷了而给骑手打差评；不因为快递放在代收点而不是送到家门口而去投诉快递。不要用「我付了钱，这是我应该享受的服务」去搪塞，这跟马克思眼中资本家会说的话一模一样，因为这就是资本主义的一个陷阱——支付价格就能无限地免除责任，这当然是不行的。 当然也有很多人说，仅靠社会上一小撮人的行动也不见得能改变整体景象，个体的声量太小了。我们需要明白，社会偏好是可以被少数人塑造的，现在的黑产羊毛党，他们也是少数人，但却影响着当下电商的发展方向。 再退一步讲，做一点事，总比什么也不做更好。 Reference 拼多多事件：除了抱怨 996，你真的在乎吗？ 美团与饿了么的方案，我们在他人困境中的角色

posts.title: 2020 年度总结 | 我们只是假装关心
posts.text: Photo by Tingey Injury Law Firm on Unsplash 第二篇年度总结的内容我想了很久，半个月前郑爽代孕的事件在发酵的时候，我其实写了一篇关于代孕的文章，但后来网络上舆论导向实在太难看，我就感觉可能需要进一步思考写点新东西。然而都没过几天，新的新闻爆出，大家又一窝蜂地去关注另一个大新闻，前一个新闻就只留下了一堆几周后就会过时的梗。 互联网是否有记忆这个问题，其实一点意义都没有。在互联网出来之前，人们通过电视、广播和报纸获取信息，这些媒介长期储存信息能力比互联网低多了，别说几周前了，昨天《新闻联播》的内容很多人今天就忘得差不多了。所以「互联网是否有记忆」这个表述，不过是把互联网里人的思想问题归咎为技术这一表层而已。 诚然，热搜榜每时每刻都在变动，我们的注意力也在随着转移，但人的记忆其实很难抹除，特别是那些难以解决的我们关心的事。有什么事是难以解决但我们非常关心的呢？好像有很多，既有中美之争、疫情防控、女权这些非常宏观的问题，也有饭圈之争、「打倒」某个 KOL 这样非常具体的问题，这样的问题都能引起非常剧烈的讨论，但最后，这之中的绝大多数问题都随着新问题的到来而被遗忘。 当然，你可以用「紧急」和「重要」划分的维度来给问题的所谓重要性排个序，但这个排序显然非常具有随意性，一个与之前事件相关的新事件一出来，一些本来被划为「不紧急不重要」的事就能瞬间被推到舆论舞台中央。 所以对此我的解释很简单：我们其实一点也不关心。这不是什么技术的问题，我们可以上一秒感叹一位孩子的离世，下一秒刷到一条偶像的动态又投入到娱乐，不是因为算法，而是我们根本就不关心。时代当然有自己的问题，现代化的城市社会，确实让人都陷入一种快速变动的生活之中，但正因如此，当我们试图去就某个问题发表自己的观点，我们不关心的样子就显得尤为突出。 你可能会问：如果我们不关心，为什么还会在网上造出如此大的声浪呢？因为我们想表现出我们很关心的样子。如果你去看当下公共论理，你会发现，尽管有讲道理的人，但是这些道理不管用多么看似华丽的语词包装，归纳起来都很简单：饭圈的争斗的道理是「不能干涉其他人的正当权利」，女权的道理是「女性不应该被物化」，质疑媒体的道理是「媒体应该为人民说话」，难道这么简单的道理，争辩的对方都不懂吗？不是的，不管是说这套道理的人，还是听这套道理的人，都不是不知道这些道理大家其实都明白。为什么不去深挖一下道理，去想应该怎么解决问题呢？因为我们不关心。我们只想用发表在公共场所的言辞证明自己是一个非常正义的人，希望获得他人的肯定而已，事情根本就不重要。 如今的公共舆论场，看来看去不过是这几类言论：上面说的那种简单道理，或使用极端语词发泄情绪，以及称赞上面两类言论。前段时间代孕事件发酵的时候，我朋友圈有一位女性朋友，写了一段非常「慷慨激昂」的话（当然在我看来不过是修辞术），然后借着「你们自己也没做多好」的道德高地把评论她的男性都骂了一遍，我不知道她凭借这条朋友圈产生了什么外部性效应，不过她个人的道德表演倒是完成得相当不错，自我满足感绝对非常强。 然而这一点用都没有，没有人去思考更为具体的道理，没有人提出具体诉求去解决问题，那我们的发声还有什么用呢？在评论区 @ 这 @ 那，这就是我们口中的推进问题解决的方式？要我说，这样下去问题只可能越来越多，社交媒体最后会越来越变得像一个「充满问题」的地方，舆论本身也会愈发失去意义。 那么我们可以做什么吗？当然，和上一篇文章一样，我又得提那种「简单却不切实际」的建议了：放弃使用大道理，而是在具体问题上反思大道理。例如在女性角度看代孕，很多女性朋友都认为代孕就是对女性的物化，但是这样一概而论，当然忽视了很多细节。 譬如女性选择在 20-30 岁时冷冻卵子作为「后悔药」，这算不算掌控自己的身体？大部分女性的最佳生育期和其事业快速发展期是重叠的，有部分女性在其最佳生育年龄并没有生育愿望。但等到事业稳定下来后，可能就会有生育意愿，然而此时若错过了最佳生育年龄，卵子质量和子宫状态可能远不如之前，那么在这种情况下是否可以选择使用自己冷冻的卵子，使用他人子宫进行代孕？一位女性在其最佳生育年龄段选择追寻事业而不是回归家庭，这不也是女权主义的叙事吗？当然你也可以继续反驳这个例子，但我的目的并不在此，我只是想说当我们越来越具体地反思这些大道理时，你会发现，那些看似人人都懂的简单大道理，其实也并没有那么简单。 最后，我写这个话题的目的，也并不希望大家认为我们在过一个非常糟糕的生活，恰恰相反，我认为我们应该摆脱对于那些「唯一真理」的依赖，去想象另一种可能性，我们不必希望论辩对方按着我们的希望转换观念，我们自己转换观念，其实最终结果会好很多。 Reference 在充分感到疼痛前，我不感兴趣那些宏大的道理 翻电 Special 互联网道理争辩的面相学 VOL.37 翻电 Special
